fields.value: Replication data for: Investigating Political Dynamics Using Fractional Integration Methods

authorAffiliation.value: Department of Political Science, Ohio State University

dsDescriptionValue.value: Many questions central to political science, such as the issue of stability and change in the United States party system, revolve around the degree of persistence or memory in a political process. Fractional integration techniques, which allow researchers to investigate dynamic behavior that falls between the stationary and integrated alternatives, provide more precise ways to test hypotheses about the degree of persistence than current modeling strategies. Hypotheses: Choices about the treatment of the time series properties of the data and model specification may influence the substantive conclusions drawn about the dynamics of important political processes. Methods: Fractional integration methods are discussed and compared with common univariate diagnostic tests. A transfer function model of macropartisanship using fractional integration techniques is contrasted with traditional ARMA and ARIMA methods. Results: Fractional integration techniques offer a more flexible way to model a time series. Using fractional integration techniques, we find that macropartisanship is dominated by a strong permanent component, but also contains transitory dynamics in response to changes in economic evaluations and a measure of presidential approval. Our empirical work shows the importance of taking seriously the time series properties of data to ensure valid inferences about the dynamics of political processes.

publicationCitation.value: Box-Steffensmeier, Janet M., and Renée M. Smith. 1998. "Investigating Political Dynamics Using Fractional Integration Methods." American Journal of Political Science, v. 42, no.2 (April): 661-89. article available here

files.description: An ASCII file containing variables in the following order presidential approval (pure, not the political portion), consumer sentiment, macropartisanship, a dummy variable for the party of the president, an events variable, an dummy variable for the assassination attempt on Reagan's life, a dummy variable for the Iran hostage crisis, battle deaths during the Vietnam War, and a dummy variable for the Watergate scandal.
files.label: AJPS2.DAT

dataFile.description: An ASCII file containing variables in the following order presidential approval (pure, not the political portion), consumer sentiment, macropartisanship, a dummy variable for the party of the president, an events variable, an dummy variable for the assassination attempt on Reagan's life, a dummy variable for the Iran hostage crisis, battle deaths during the Vietnam War, and a dummy variable for the Watergate scandal.

files.description: Tables created in WordPerfect 6.1 that provide the empirical results for ADF, KPSS, and variance ratio tests upon which we based the conclusions we summarize in Table 3 of the paper.
files.label: DIAGNOSE.TAB

dataFile.description: Detailed information on the files used in this study

files.description: A Rats batch file that contains commands for the creation of new variables (presidential administration dummy variables, other event variables, variables multiplied by the party variable, the political portion of approval, etc.), commands to fractionally difference macropartisanship (requires the fif.src source code available from Estima at http://www.estima.com), commands to estimate the ARMA, ARFIMA, and ARIMA models in Table 5, and commands to generate the data that are graphed in Figure 2 of the paper.
files.label: TAB5CODE.PRG

dataFile.description: A Rats batch file that contains commands for the creation of new variables (presidential administration dummy variables, other event variables, variables multiplied by the party variable, the political portion of approval, etc.), commands to fractionally difference macropartisanship (requires the fif.src source code available from Estima at http://www.estima.com), commands to estimate the ARMA, ARFIMA, and ARIMA models in Table 5, and commands to generate the data that are graphed in Figure 2 of the paper.
